case_vignette: A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother because of persistent crying and refusal to move his right arm. The episode began 30 minutes ago after the mother lifted him up by the arms. He appears distressed and is inconsolable. On examination, his right arm is held close to his body in a flexed and pronated position.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I can't stop crying and I don't want to move my right arm.
How old are you?
I'm 2 years old.
Are you able to use your right arm at all?
No, I'm not using my right arm.
Did you have a fall or injury recently?
My arm started hurting after my mom lifted me up by the arms.
Do you have any swelling, bruising, or deformity on your right arm?
No, there's no swelling, bruising, or deformity.
Is there any pain when your arm is touched or moved?
Yes, it hurts when my arm is touched or moved.
Final Diagnosis: Nursemaid's elbow (radial head subluxation)

trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Right upper extremity fracture or injury.
